I get the same errors too with g++5.3 && cuda7.5

```
/mnt/disk/0/hzxiahouzuoxin/usr/gcc-5.3/include/c++/5.3.0/bits/stl_iterator_base_types.h(158): error: name followed by "::" must be a class or namespace name
          detected during:
            instantiation of class "std::__iterator_traits<_Iterator, void> [with _Iterator=int]" 
(163): here
            instantiation of class "std::iterator_traits<_Iterator> [with _Iterator=int]" 
src/operator/./sequence_reverse-inl.h(91): here
            implicit generation of "mxnet::op::SequenceReverseOp<xpu, DType>::~SequenceReverseOp() [with xpu=mxnet::gpu, DType=float]" 
src/operator/./sequence_reverse-inl.h(45): here
            instantiation of class "mxnet::op::SequenceReverseOp<xpu, DType> [with xpu=mxnet::gpu, DType=float]" 
src/operator/./sequence_reverse-inl.h(45): here
            instantiation of "mxnet::op::SequenceReverseOp<xpu, DType>::SequenceReverseOp(mxnet::op::SequenceReverseParam) [with xpu=mxnet::gpu, DType=float]" 
src/operator/sequence_reverse.cu(14): here
```
It seems that cuda7.5 not support this vector initialization mode in `src/operator/sequence_reverse-inl.h`
```c++
std::vector<index_t> indices_vec(n, max_seq_len);
```
I change to 
```c++
std::vector<index_t> indices_vec(n/*, max_seq_len*/);
// Init by this way for GPU support
for (int k = 0; k < n; ++k) {
    indices_vec[k] = max_seq_len;
}
```
All is OK!
@alexy you can refer to #4551 and #4469

May I ask how do you handle image of (50,100). I think im2rec will resize this case to (100,200). There is a resize parameter for ImageRecordIter class too. But the data.py file in tutorial did not included it.

you dont have to write forward and backward if you can implement the operator using mshadow.
The ```CreateOp``` is needed for creating GPU operator.
You can refer to these 2 links:
[new_op](http://mxnet.io/how_to/new_op.html#c)
[mshadow tutorial](https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/tree/master/guide)
Please review it.

when use one layer architecture the output is fine.
when use multiple layers architecture the output is nan.

data is ok, it works fine for one layer network
the same thing should be done in ```.cu``` file.

net = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
        net = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=net, name='teacher_fc1', num_hidden=400)
        net = mx.symbol.Activation(data=net, name='teacher_relu1', act_type="relu")
        net = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=net, name='teacher_fc2', num_hidden=400)
        net = mx.symbol.Activation(data=net, name='teacher_relu2', act_type="relu")
        net = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=net, name='teacher_fc3', num_hidden=1)
        net = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=net, name='teacher_output',
                                               grad_scale=teacher_noise_precision)

I am not sure if second part is needed.

@hetong007

The build fail is due to the vignette: fiveMinutesNeuralNetwork.R

graph.viz now takes symbol as parameter so need to change line 28 to `graph.viz(model$symbol)` instead of `graph.viz(model$symbol$as.json())`. 
Other vignettes such as MNIST and RNNchar could now display the network if desired. 

DESCRIPTION file should as well be updated to import visNetwork(>= 1.0.3). 

Should I submit a new pull with the above updates?

Not sure if I should open another issue for this, but when I try to fit my FeedForward  that ends with
``` scala
   val numClasses = 8
(...)
    val fc8 = Symbol.FullyConnected("fc8")()(Map("data" -> drop7, "num_hidden" -> numClasses))
    val label = Symbol.Variable("label")
    val softmax = Symbol.SoftmaxOutput()()(Map("data" -> fc8, "label" -> label))

```
with a categorical ouptut encoded with NDArray.onehotEncode, I get a Shape mismatch error:
`[error] (run-main-0) java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: requirement failed: label (32,8) and prediction (32)should have the same length.`
However, it seems correct that the Shape of label is (32,8) as the batchSize is 32 and the number of oneHotEncode output (= number of classes) is 8.
With the above network, why is the Shape of output of the FeedForward (32) instead of (32,8)?
Is it a bug, should I open a new issue or did I miss something?

On mobile device SGD will be very slow if you will use naive style transfer implementation. Actualy, you don't need backprop-pass for style transfer, only forward pass. There is a lot of articles, that describe how to implement fast version of style transfer (for example https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.08155 and https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.07629) in feed-forward model.
Could you be more specific which file I should change? I am running inception-bn neural network in the mxnet/example/image-classsification. I am still not familiar with MXNet code structure. Thanks.
@precedenceguo

@benqua the label shape should be just (batchSize), you don't need to do one hot yourself.
Also the error message should come from EvalMetric.scala.

rnn_cell_demo.py named built in RNN parameters as "LSTM_bias", which is initialized as all zero. It significantly reduces the convergence speed. I changed the initializer and acquired similar convergence speed like others.
I have just encountered this again. Features that require specific cuda/cuDNN versions should check for them and either disable themselves or print a error message that prompts the user to update.

Apart from the fact that compile failed, the change is wrong. If you pool a (1000, 1000) map into (10, 10) and phstart is 0, then phend is 100. phend isn't necessarily phstart + 1.

Additionally, I propose to move ROIPooling into example/rcnn/operator in order to remove a strange operator for users who have nothing to do with object detection.

No idea why the old code works in my experiments but your change is correct according to numpy reference. You might want to rebase your changes.

I agree with most of your suggestions, especially for the RNN and IO things.
To modify the `kwargs` argument, we have to detect the arguments (with their types) of registered C++ functions, which may encounter some difficulties. Currently the c api doc may not be well defined for programs, e.g., the types. We need to check all the operators to make sure `scala macros` can get enough information.

`kwargs` is difficult to deal with. How about relinquishing macros and do it manually? Or retain those APIs with `kwargs` as low-level API and wrap them up in an idiomatic way as the high-level API (prototypical example: https://github.com/ctongfei/nexus-mxnet/blob/master/src/main/scala/nexus/mxnet/Expr.scala#L51)

I'm working on a run interface for python. You can use it as a reference.
It's currently sitting in pull request

@ctongfei Thanks for your suggestions. In my opinion, I think the high-level api you designed is good but a little hard to understand. Because I am not very famililar with the High-level syntax of Scala. Those users come from java side may encounter the same problem when they try to read the source code.
Also this is just my personal opinion.

@Ldpe2G what about this? (https://github.com/ctongfei/nexus-mxnet/blob/master/src/test/scala/nexus/mxnet/MNIST.scala#L17)

Or we could first publish a simple, clean Java API instead of a Scala one (java has a much larger audience), and then delegate all those fancy stuffs to Scala.
@ctongfei ok I see. Users could construct a net with less code and a more elegant way.
Wow, Thanks @sandeep-krishnamurthy. I will polish this doc based on your comments.
@ctongfei The arguments for `FullyConnected`, and the name `FullyConnected` itself should be automatically generated. Otherwise it'll be too hard to sync with the cpp core.
@javelinjs It'd be desirable if it could be automatically generated. Is the c++ core constantly changing?

I don't think doing it manually is a good idea. That really suffered so we turned to code generation. The operators can be added, deprecated, so as their arguments. And from the view of design, those changes should not be done twice, in core and its front-end binding. 

I think what we need to do is to ensure that scala macros can correctly parse the c++ api doc, especially for the argument types.

BTW, your api design in `nexus-mxnet` is quite cool.
can you clone the notebook repo in script instead of committing them into mxnet repo

Got it. I'll read the scala macro code to see if there something I can do.
@piiswrong @sbodenstein I plan to merge this in.

@ctongfei I fully agree that a more idiomatic scala API would be great (an API that take more advantage of the type system).

I would add one point:
- use Option[T] instead of null default value for optional parameters

I am willing to help if an effort in this direction is started.
@d4wud Hi, I met this trouble too. Do you succeed now?

Option 1 , move to Executor could not be done because arg_param is create from python

a.	For weight & aux parameters
1.	FeedForward _init_params, model.py:513
Init ndarray for arg_params
=> arg_params = {k : nd.zeros(s) for k, s in param_name_shapes}
=>  <type 'list'>: ['conv1_weight', 'conv1_bias', 'bn1_gamma', 'bn1_beta', 'conv2_weight', 'conv2_bias', 'bn2_gamma', 'bn2_beta', 'fc2_weight', 'fc2_bias']
Init ndarray for aux_params
=> aux_params = {k : nd.zeros(s) for k, s in zip(aux_names, aux_shapes)}
=> <type 'list'>: ['bn1_moving_mean', 'bn1_moving_var', 'bn2_moving_mean', 'bn2_moving_var']
2.	_bind_exec, executor_manager.py:154 （duplicate allocate）
arg_arrays: arg_arr = nd.zeros(arg_shape[i], ctx, dtype=arg_types[i])
aux_arrays: aux_arrays = [nd.zeros(s, ctx, dtype=t) for s, t in zip(aux_shape, aux_types)]
3.	sym.bind(python) MXExecutorBindEX(C++)
assign to data_entry_
data_entry_[idx.entry_id(nid, 0)] = in_args[arg_top];
 
4.	assign to ForwardOpExecutor’s in_array
    for (const auto& e : inode.inputs) {
      exec->in_array.push_back(data_entry_[idx.entry_id(e)]);
    }
 
5.	ForwardOpExecutor=> setup
Assign in_data_ according to in_array
 
6.	ForwardOpExecutor=> run
op_->Forward(op_ctx, in_data_, req, out_data_, aux_data_)
 
b.	For output
1.	GraphExecutor::InitDataEntryMemory
Get NDarray from pool
    	    const NDArray& src = data_pool_.at(storage_id);
    data_entry_[i] = src.AsArray(vshape[i], vdtype[i]);
